org.springframework.web.servlet.view
Class JspTemplateViewResolver

java.lang.Object
  org.springframework.context.support.ApplicationObjectSupport
      org.springframework.web.context.support.WebApplicationObjectSupport
          org.springframework.web.servlet.view.AbstractCachingViewResolver
              org.springframework.web.servlet.view.UrlBasedViewResolver
                  org.springframework.web.servlet.view.InternalResourceViewResolver
                      org.springframework.web.servlet.view.JspTemplateViewResolver
All Implemented Interfaces:
org.springframework.context.ApplicationContextAware, org.springframework.core.Ordered, org.springframework.web.context.ServletContextAware, org.springframework.web.servlet.ViewResolver
public class JspTemplateViewResolver
extends org.springframework.web.servlet.view.InternalResourceViewResolver

Class JspTemplateViewResolver is a ViewResolver implementation that supports automatic decoration of JSP views with a view template. JspTemplateViewResolver can be used in Spring MVC projects based on the JSP rendering-technology as a drop-in replacement to InternalResourceViewResolver and org.springframework.web.servlet.view.tiles.TilesViewResolver.

JspTemplateViewResolver extends InternalResourceViewResolver, so the features implemented by its parent class, such as view logical name resolution based on properties UrlBasedViewResolver.prefix and UrlBasedViewResolver.suffix, are also available. JspTemplateViewResolver differs from org.springframework.web.servlet.view.tiles.TilesViewResolver in that it does not require a third-party dependency on Tiles and does not require the use of external view description files (e.g. tiles.xml) Additionally, JspTemplateViewResolver does not makes use of dedicated TagLibs to define or use templates. The template view uses the JSP standard tag <jsp:include > and a Java or EL expression to include page specific content. JSTL can optionally be used to support for page title resolution and i18n. An example basic configuration in a Spring beans XML file is shown below: 

<bean class="org.springframework.web.servlet.view.JspTemplateViewResolver">
   <constructor-arg value="layout/standard"/>
   <property name="prefix" value="/WEB-INF/views/" />
   <property name="suffix" value=".jsp" />
 </bean>
, or alternatively: 
<bean class="org.springframework.web.servlet.view.JspTemplateViewResolver">
   <property name="defaultTemplateName" value="layout/standard"/>
   <property name="prefix" value="/WEB-INF/views/" />
   <property name="suffix" value=".jsp" />
 </bean>
With the above setting the template resource file is located in path: /WEB-INF/views/layout/standard.jsp There are two key points to follow to write template view for JspTemplateViewResolver:
  1. The view main content page is inserted with: 
    <jsp:include page="${viewUrl}" />
  2. The view title is resolved (and localized) with: 
    <fmt:setBundle basename="titles" var="titlesBundle" />
   <title><fmt:message key="${viewTitle}" bundle="${titlesBundle}"/></title>
When an implementation of MessageSource is configured in available in the application context, there is no need to explicitly define the property bundle with <fmt:setBundle> , since the ResourceBundle object is automatically exported. Below, is an an example template JSP view that can used as starting point or blueprint for application template views. 
<%@ page ... %>
 <%@ taglib prefix="fmt" uri="http://java.sun.com/jsp/jstl/fmt" %>
 <html>
 <head>
	 <fmt:setBundle basename="titles" var="titlesBundle" />
   <title><fmt:message key="${viewTitle}" bundle="${titlesBundle}"/></title>
   ...
 </head>
 <body> 
   <jsp:include page="common/header.jsp" />

   <jsp:include page="${viewUrl}" />

   <jsp:include page="common/footer.jsp" />
 </body>
 </html>
The property file for titles (named titles.properties for the example view above) will typically look something like this: 
#titles.properties
 view.title.account.list=Account List
 view.title.account.show=Account Details
 #....
 *
In addition to a default template name configured in property defaultTemplateName, templates can also be selected based patterns on the view name. This is done by configuring the property templateNameMap. If no match is found on the templateNameMap, then template selection falls-back to defaultTemplateName. An example configuration setting templateNameMap is shown below: 
<bean class="org.springframework.web.servlet.view.JspTemplateViewResolver">
   <property name="prefix" value="/WEB-INF/views/"/>
   <property name="suffix" value=".jsp"/>
   <property name="templateNameMap">
     <map>
       <entry key="account/.*" value="common/standard-account"/>
     </map>
	 </property>
   <property name="usePatterns" value="true" />
	 <property name="defaultTemplateName" value="common/standard"/>
 </bean>
The use of pattern needs to be explicitly set, otherwise the keys in are simply looked up by view name. Patterns are specified using Java regular expression. (In futures versions, additional pattern languages may be supported.) View decoration can be prevented on a per-request basis, by setting the value of the HTTP request parameter layoutParam equals to cancelLayoutParamValue). This is useful, for example, to support partial-page rendering driven by JavaScript+AJAX requests. With the default configuration, view decoration is canceled by setting HTTP request parameter "layout=none". This can be also overridden by setting properties layoutParam and/or cancelLayoutParamValue. Template selection can be made on a per-request basis, by setting property dynamicTemplates to true. With this setting the request parameter layoutParam is interpreted as the name of the template (except when is equal to cancelLayoutParamValue).

Since:
22.11.2011
Author:
Jorge Simão (original concept, design, implementation, documentation), Rossen Stoyanchev (design contributions, and samples)
See Also:
DecoratedInternalResourceView, setDefaultTemplateName(String), setLayoutParam(String), setCancelLayoutParamValue(String), setDynamicTemplates(boolean), InternalResourceView

Field Detail

LAYOUT_PARAM

public static final java.lang.String LAYOUT_PARAM
Default name for layoutParam

See Also:
Constant Field Values

CANCEL_LAYOUT

public static final java.lang.String CANCEL_LAYOUT
Default name for cancelLayoutParamValue

See Also:
Constant Field Values

TEMPLATE_NAME_CHAR

public static final java.lang.String TEMPLATE_NAME_CHAR
Character separator between template name and view name (default '+'). Controller handler methods can return string value such as 'templateName+viewName}, to explicitly specify a template name in additional to the usual view name.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

templateNameMap

protected java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> templateNameMap
Map from viewNames to templates. Recommended to be set as a LinkedHashMap<String, String>() in order to keep preserve search order. (When configured from a Spring bean file, not really possible because its not yet supported by or elements).

defaultTemplateName

protected java.lang.String defaultTemplateName
Logical name of template view.

layoutParam

protected java.lang.String layoutParam
Name of HTTP request parameter to check for the per-request template names and/or cancel page template-based decoration.

cancelLayoutParamValue

protected java.lang.String cancelLayoutParamValue
Value for the HTTP parameter requesting partial rendering. If the value of HTTP parameter named with the value of layoutParam is equal to cancelLayoutParamValue then it is a partial rendering request and no template-based decoration is performed.

dynamicTemplates

protected boolean dynamicTemplates
Specifies if template selection can be done on a per-request basis.

cacheTemplatesNames

protected boolean cacheTemplatesNames
Specifies if template name selection for views should be cached. Ignored if templateNameMap is null.

usePatterns

protected boolean usePatterns
Specifies is templateNameMap entries contains patterns.

cachePatterns

protected boolean cachePatterns
Specifies if Pattern objects should be cached. Ignored if templateNameMap is null.

Method Detail

getTemplateNameMap

public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> getTemplateNameMap()
Get the value of templateNameMap.

Returns:
the templateNameMap

setTemplateNameMap

public void setTemplateNameMap(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> templateNameMap)
Set the value of templateNameMap. Recommended to be set as a LinkedHashMap() in order to keep preserve search order. When configured from a Spring bean file, the XML name-space can be used for this purpose. The template map is not consulted in any of the following conditions:
  • it is null;
  • dynamicTemplates is true, and the request includes the layout HTTP request parameter;
  • the name of the view contains character TEMPLATE_NAME_CHAR ('+')
  • a matching cache entry is found

Parameters:
templateNameMap - the value of templateNameMap to set

getDefaultTemplateName

public java.lang.String getDefaultTemplateName()
Get the value of defaultTemplateName.

Returns:
the value of defaultTemplateName

setDefaultTemplateName

public void setDefaultTemplateName(java.lang.String defaultTemplateName)
Set the value of the the default template view defaultTemplateName. This the name of the template that is used when the map templateNameMap is not set, or there is no matching entry in the map. The default template not used in the following conditions:
  • dynamicTemplates is true, and the request includes the layout HTTP request parameter;
  • the name of the view contains character TEMPLATE_NAME_CHAR ('+');
  • a matching cache entry is found templateNameCache;
  • a matching entry is found in templateNameMap;

Parameters:
defaultTemplateName - the value of defaultTemplateName to set

getLayoutParam

public java.lang.String getLayoutParam()
Get the value of layoutParam. Name of HTTP request parameter to check for the per-request template names and/or cancel page template-based decoration.

Returns:
the value of layoutParam

setLayoutParam

public void setLayoutParam(java.lang.String layoutParam)
Set the value of layoutParam. Name of HTTP request parameter to check for the per-request template names and/or cancel page template-based decoration.

Parameters:
layoutParam - the value of layoutParam to set

getCancelLayoutParamValue

public java.lang.String getCancelLayoutParamValue()
Get the value of cancelLayoutParamValue. If the value of HTTP parameter named with the value of layoutParam is equal to cancelLayoutParamValue no template-based decoration is performed. This is useful to support partial page rendering, or simply see page markup without the template decorations.

Returns:
the value of cancelLayoutParamValue

setCancelLayoutParamValue

public void setCancelLayoutParamValue(java.lang.String cancelLayoutParamValue)
Set the value of cancelLayoutParamValue.

Parameters:
cancelLayoutParamValue - the value of cancelLayoutParamValue to be set

public boolean isDynamicTemplates()
Get the value of dynamicTemplates. If template selection can be done on a per-request basis, by setting the value of HTTP request parameter layoutParam.

Returns:
true, if template selection can be done on a per-request basis; false, otherwise.

Set the value of dynamicTemplates. If template selection can be done on a per-request basis, by setting the value of HTTP request parameter layoutParam.

Parameters:
dynamicTemplates - true, if template selection can be done on a per-request basis; false, otherwise.

setCacheTemplate

public void setCacheTemplate(boolean cacheTemplateNames)
Set the value of cacheTemplatesNames. If the value is true then the mapping between view names and templates are cached.

Parameters:

isCachePatterns

public boolean isCachePatterns()
Get the value of cachePatterns.

Returns:
the cachePatterns

setCachePatterns

public void setCachePatterns(boolean cachePatterns)
Set the value of cachePatterns. If true created view name regular expression Pattern objects are cached (default). Pattern objects are created only if usePatterns is true.

Parameters:
cachePatterns - the value cachePatterns to set

isUsePatterns

public boolean isUsePatterns()
Get the value of usePatterns.

Returns:
true, if templateNameMap entries contain patterns; false, otherwise.

setUsePatterns

public void setUsePatterns(boolean usePatterns)
Set the value of usePatterns. A value of true specified that templateNameMap contains view name patterns. If the value is false, lookup in templateNameMap is performed by simple map key resolution (Map.get()). If the value is true, lookup if first attempted by key resolution and then by iteration over patterns to check for matches.

Parameters:
usePatterns - true, if templateNameMap entries contain patterns; false, otherwise (default).

Build resource path for the specified viewName. (This function should be moved to InternalResourceViewResolver)

Parameters:
viewName - the name of the view to build the resource path
Returns:
the resource path for the view.

getViewName

protected java.lang.String getViewName(java.lang.String viewName)
Extract viewName from string returned by controller handler method. If the string contains the character TEMPLATE_NAME_CHAR ('+' by default), the view name is the part after that character. Otherwise, the view name is the string returned by the controller unchanged.

Parameters:
viewName - the string returned by controller
Returns:
the actual view name.

getTemplateName

public java.lang.String getTemplateName(java.lang.String viewName)
Get name of template to use for a view name based on templateNameMap. Current implementation:
  1. Check if view name string returned by controller handler method specifies an explicit template with syntax: templateName+viewName
  2. Checks if a mapping between the view name and template are been cached
  3. Checks for exact match between view name and key in templateNameMap
  4. Iterates over set of entries and templateNameMap and check for a pattern match.
  5. Falls-back to defaultTemplateName.
Note: Although the mapping between viewNames and View objects are cached by InternalResourceViewResolver this feature can be disabled. So the mapping between viewName and templateName is also cached by this class. Note: This method should be protected or private, from the purely functional perspective. However, it is made public to allow unit testing of the configuration.

Parameters:
viewName - the view name to find the template name.
Returns:
the template name.

putTemplateName

protected void putTemplateName(java.lang.String viewName,
                               java.lang.String templateName)
Save viewName to templateName map entry. Does nothing if caching is disabled as specified by property cacheTemplatesNames

Parameters:
viewName - the view name
templateName - the template name

matchesViewName

protected boolean matchesViewName(java.lang.String key,
                                  java.lang.String viewName)
Checks if a view name pattern matches a view name.

Parameters:
key - the view name pattern.
viewName - the view name to match.
Returns:
true, if there is a match; false, otherwise.
